div.p: I shd not have let others be before me in men- -tioning my little woman's intended wedding, but that at the time when I found her romance near its last chapter, I was afflicted sadly by recurring reports of evil abot her uncle in India which indeed [underline]for me[/underline] made it impossible [unclear]to enter[/unclear] rightly at the feelings of the younger generation. Moreover I was then as I am still in a poor uncomfortable state of health myself - but of that no more. And I know how heartily you will rejoice that I can now

report favourably as this W. [unclear][/unclear] I had by last mail a letter from himself dated 22[superscript]d[/superscript] October. He had removed on the 10[superscript]th[/superscript] to the home of a friend of his & relation & namesake of mine some few miles on the way frm Bangalore to Madras. During the intervening days he had been sensibly gathering strength & he & his wife & his host (whose letters also I have seen) concurred in thinking that he w[superscript]d[/superscript] speedily be able to continue his journey and embark for England. He cd have no other chance but in the sea voyage & home of a [note]48[/note] permanent care after a most severe case of [unclear]abscess[/unclear] in the liver. I hope & trust I shall have him here anon & that his constitution may have so rallied as [unclear]&[/unclear] to afford him the prospect of a tranquil Evening of life in the country. That he shd be well enough for active service, at least for several years to come, my medical friends assure me is in the highest degree improbable. Since you will not come to Londn I must go to Ireland & bye & bye I am likely to be a free batchelor

Eugh! My son is daily expecting to join his regimt at Canterbury & Miss Charlotte will I suppose be taken fr me at Easter or at latest in the Summer. They are both now in Scotland where had I been well engh to travel I shd have been w them at Chrs for line season - but that over they will come up without delay. They have had a very happy Summer & Autum there & [underline]he[/underline] may not have the like again for years to come.

[note]49[/note] Charlotte will be a terrible loss to my fireside - but I must consider how soon the railway is to annihilate distance - & let any rate I am not so silly as to let my thoughts rest on anything but the great comfort of knowing that she is to be provided w a kind protector of her own standing in place of[insertion]a[/insertion] worn & weary papa I think myself entitled to count on [unclear]her[/unclear] many chances chances

as most fathers ought to anticipate of a tranquil & happy lot for my child: & the residence of her [underline]promisso[/underline] is within 15 miles of my brother's place, so that in days to come her brother & she are likely to be my neighbours I know well that you [unclear]have had[/unclear] Sad new affliction - but nothing 1846 De[superscript]f[/superscript] Mr Lockhart
[note]50[/note can ever render you indifferent to either the good or the evil that befals a friend - I hope Mrs Wilson when she must leave you is to bring me some comfortable tidings
